Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Research Training in Physiology - Integrating Biology Across the Scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Founded in 1892, The Marine Biology Laboratory (MBL) Physiology Course is one of the oldest, continually-running biology courses in the World. This training course remains a "Gold Standard" for bringing together faculty, and students selected from a highly qualified pool, across many disciplines in the life sciences. The instructors work closely as a cohesive team to educate early-career biologists, many of whom go on to make their own ground-breaking discoveries. The MBL Physiology Course fosters a unique training environment that uses cellular, molecular, and physical principles of biology to understand living organisms. This NSF award will be used to integrate cellular and genomic science with principles and practices of organismal and evolutionary biology. Faculty and students will combine their unique perspectives to problem solving in physiology. By so doing, a deeper understanding of the physiological principles of "How Life Works" will be attained and integrated across biological subdisciplines. To extend the learning experience beyond the time that each trainee spends at the MBL, instructors in the MBL Physiology Course will invite and support teams of students to continue to work together after they return to their respective research groups at their home institutions. Through this post-course experience, each participant will have the opportunity to engage and educate the general public regarding fundamental principles of living organisms, related to the societal importance of new knowledge and discovery in the life sciences.

The MBL Physiology Course provides intensive training and research experiences at critical intersections of cell biology and physical science - ranging from molecular biology, genetics, genomics, to evolutionary biology. The course begins with an intensive "Boot Camp," when biologists, physicists, and all students become familiar with cutting-edge techniques in cellular anatomy and physiology, fabrication, bioinformatics, while working together to analyze big data sets. The revised MBL Physiology Course will now incorporate interactions with three other concurrent summer courses to bring physiology "back into the organism" and challenge students to consider cells in their natural contexts. Intentionally bringing students together from the Physiology, Microbial Diversity, Embryology, and Biology of Parasites courses will provide opportunities for synergism of ideas and expanded multidisciplinary perspectives inherent in this horizontal integration across biological subdisciplines. The MBL Physiology Course trains a diverse student body, with specific attention given to the recruitment and support of under-represented groups in STEM. In addition, the course will aid students in disseminating techniques and concepts via support of organized groups at the students' home institutions and at scientific conferences.

This award is cofunded by the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Projects: Advanced Research Training in

Physiology - Integrating Biology Across Integrating Biology Across the Scales 

PI: Linda Hyman 

Organization: Marine Biological Laboratory

 The Physiology - Integrating Biology Across the Scales Advanced Research Training Course provides intensive cutting-edge training for advanced graduate students postdoctoral fellows, that provides a platform for integrating scientific training across disciplines both horizontally (within the biological sciences) and vertically (with physics, chemistry and computational sciences). The course’s focus on “Modern Cell Biology” is interpreted broadly and has grown to encompass topics and research in cell physiology, molecular biology, developmental biology, pathology, biophysics and evolutionary genetics This course, combined with MBL’s rich intellectual and research environment, provided a unique training stage to to build “horizontal integration” into the fabric of the existing course by adding both formal, structured elements (joint lectures, joint brainstorming, and joint research projects) and informal elements (shared workshops, coffee breaks, social events) that bring together participants in the concurrent advanced courses. An additional element will allow students from across the summer courses to work together post-course, bringing an outreach project to regional sites. The main objectives of this proposal were to: Objective I. To train the next generation of leaders in Cell Biology through delivery of the interdisciplinary 7-week Physiology course at MBL; Objective II. To create a new paradigm for training across biological disciplines by building educational bridges between the Physiology course and 3 concurrent MBL courses in different fields of biology; and Objective III. Broader Impacts: To build a post-course program in which teams of MBL summer course alumni partner to create outreach activities in their local regions.

During the period of the NSF Award 2014108 (2021 -2023) the Physiology course operated for seven weeks during June and July from 2020-2023, and it was led by Dan Fletcher and Nicole King, both from University of California Berkeley. During this time, there were 171 applicants of which 65 (38%) students were accepted. The three-year student cohort was comprised of 48 (73.8%) graduate students, 16 (24.6%) postdoctoral fellows, and 1 (1.5%) were faculty

Over the three-year award, the course provided the students with a learning experience that they reported to be “transformative, eye-opening, completely exhilarating and re-ignited my love for science” in our post-course survey. Students were immersed in a seven-week intensive hands-on research experience where they completed an arc of three distinct research projects in interdisciplinary teams. Each rotation began with defining an interesting question based on the systems brought by the course faculty, formulating hypotheses, piloting experiments, refining ideas, changing course, data analysis and simulations, and were capped off by giving a talk at a research symposium. The short time for this whole cycle meant students worked intensely, exchanged ideas, and perhaps most importantly learned the value of taking risks and the power of creativity to solve a problem given many constraints. Students learn to brings new ideas, approaches and results to fundamental questions in cell biology.  

The course provides the experience of collaborative research rotations with two faculty members and TAs co-advising students on their research projects, providing students with more input, encouraging cross-disciplinary thinking, and inspiring more scientific discussion. These rotations result in a large number of post-course research requests, which allowed students to propose a project that was initiated during the course and would benefit from additional research. These Physiology projects are conducted faculty labs for periods of two or more weeks. Between 2021 and 2023 there were 34 post course research projects.   

  1. During the 2021 course, Kayla Hake participated in a project in Course Director King’s rotation. Hake reached out to Emil Ruff, resident MBL scientist and Microbial Diversity faculty member, and Julia Schwartzman, also a Microbial Diversity faculty member, to assist with early CARD FISH experiments. Based on the experimental results, Hake and King realized that the colonial choanoflagellate has a microbiome resulting in a pre-print. King and Hake have continued to study the species and demonstrated an opportunity for Physiology to interface with Microbial Diversity in the future for more studies.
  2. Actin dynamics in the acellular slime mold Physarum polycephalum: Sponsoring Faculty: Amy Gladfelter, Duke University.  
  3. Surface property driven motility of protists in synthetic and natural environments: Sponsoring Faculty: Wallace Marshall, University of California, San Francisco

In 2021 MBL developed the Alumni ROCS (Regional Outreach and Communication of STEM) Program.  This effort allowed us to enhance the interdisciplinarity of the MBL experience across the ARTCs by encouraging cross course partnerships and leverage the enthusiasm of recent ARTC trainees. 

  1. In 2023, Arthur Orszag, Physiology TA, connected with Microbial Diversity and STAMPS alumni Amaranta Kahn, Nicole Dames, and Sarah Guest to help created the “Living Like an Amoeba” International Art Exhibition (Hellenic Marine Station, Athens, Greece, Marine Biological Laboratory, Woods Hole, Ma, ISME19 microbiology conference, South Africa, cultural center of Dalvik, Iceland, Naples Zoological Station, Naples, Italy).
